Chapter 7, part 1: Distinguishing Knowledge, the first of seven parts. Thus, based on the distinctions of the various paths, the sages and ordinary beings are established. In the path that they rely on, it is said like this: right view and right knowledge are called the factors of no-more-learning.
Therefore, in this [chapter], one should carefully contemplate and discern:
Are there any knowledges that are views but not knowledges, and are there any knowledges that are knowledges but not views, that are separately established as the two factors of view and knowledge?
There are.ğŸ”½How so?
Verse:
The noble wisdom of forbearance is not knowledge, the extinction [of outflows] and non-arising [of future suffering] are not views,
The other two [types of] contaminated wisdom are all knowledge, and six [types of] wisdom are of the nature of views.
Commentary:
Wisdom is of two kinds: contaminated and uncontaminated. Only the uncontaminated wisdom is established as the noble [wisdom].
Among this noble wisdom, the eight forbearances are not of the nature of knowledge.
Why is this so?
Because it is not by nature a form of discernment, and discernment is the meaning of the term knowledge.
How is it that the eight kinds of patience are not discernment?
Because the doubt that they eliminate continues to exist in a series.
Or, it is said that knowledge is that which is characterized by a state of mind that is at rest and a state of practice that is relaxed, in the sense that one seeks to see the object of knowledge.

The eight kinds of patience are not knowledge because they are characterized by a state of mind that is engaged in investigation and a state of practice that is vigorous. However, they are called seeing because they are by nature discernment.

The two kinds of knowledge, i.e., the knowledge of destruction and the knowledge of nonproduction, are not by nature seeing, because the state of mind that is engaged in investigation is completely at rest and the state of practice that is aroused is extremely relaxed. However, they are called knowledge because they are by nature discernment.
The remaining ten kinds of knowledge are both knowledge and seeing, because they eliminate ones own doubts and are by nature discernment.

The remaining ten kinds of knowledge are the eight kinds of patience, the knowledge of destruction, and the knowledge of nonproduction.ğŸ”½The knowledge of the knowledge of the path of insight is not seeing, because it is not by nature discernment.

Isnâ€™t it true that the other uninterrupted paths are also accompanied by the acquisition of the elimination of their own obstacles, and that they are not accompanied by the intense intention of investigation and judgment? They should not be categorized as knowledge. The same is true of the other paths of liberation, etc., because they are opposed to the uninterrupted paths.
This objection is not reasonable, because the other uninterrupted paths are not accompanied by the acquisition of doubt of their own class.
Also, they only see objects that have been seen, and they are not opposed to knowledge to the same degree as the eight forbearances.
The other paths of liberation, etc., do not completely stop seeking, and the practice they arouse is not extremely lax, because they all have something to be done later.
Consequently, all are of two kinds, because they are both capable of investigating and judging.
All impure wisdom is categorized as knowledge. Among the various kinds of wisdom, only six are also insight, i.e., the five false views and right worldly views.
Other masters say:

The good and impure wisdom associated with the five consciousnesses and with the mind at the moment of death that can instigate body and speech is also not of the nature of views, because it evolves in regard to external objects, like that which instigates it, and because its power is weak.
This is not so, because it should not be admitted, because it is not certain, and because of a scriptural text.

That is, it should not be admitted that only that which evolves internally is of the nature of views, because then the external body and life in holy wisdom would not be included in the nature of views.

However, a scripture says that the contemplation of the body in the body with regard to the external body is included in the nature of views. Also, it is not certain that the mind associated with the five consciousnesses evolves in the same way as the consciousness that instigates it, because sometimes the mind associated with good, etc., is not good, etc. Consequently, the mind associated with the consciousness that instigates it is not the same in being of the nature of non discrimination.
As a scripture says,
At the moment of death, one obtains a good mind associated with right views.
Therefore it is good reasoning to say that all good discernment in the mind is of the nature of seeing. All holy wisdom that is impure is discernment of dharmas and is categorized as discernment.
How many kinds of knowledge are there? What are their specific characteristics?
A verse says:
Knowledge is generally of two kinds, with or without impurity.
Impure knowledge is called worldly, and pure knowledge is called knowledge of dharmas and of species.

Worldly knowledge has all as objects, and knowledge of dharmas and of species have as objects the truths of suffering, etc., of the realm of desire and of the realm of form and of the formless realm, respectively.
The treatise says:

Knowledge is of ten kinds, which subsume all knowledge: 1) worldly knowledge, 2) knowledge of dharmas, 3) knowledge of species, 4) knowledge of suffering, 5) knowledge of the arising of suffering, 6) knowledge of the extinction of suffering, 7) knowledge of the path, 8) knowledge of othersâ€™ minds, 9) knowledge of the exhaustion of outflows, and 10) knowledge of nonproduction.
These ten knowledges are generally of two kinds, because of the difference of being impure or pure.
These two kinds of knowledge are distinguished as three kinds: knowledge of the conventional, knowledge of the Dharma, and knowledge of the species.

The former impure knowledge is generally called knowledge of the conventional, because such things as vases and clothing are by nature perishable and appear in worldly thoughts, and it is called conventional.
This knowledge often takes conventional objects, and it often evolves in accordance with worldly affairs. It is established as the name knowledge of the conventional because it is frequent.

It is not without the ability to take the ultimate as an object and evolve in accordance with the ultimate, but it is an object of craving and does not have the superior ability to extinguish internal passions and is therefore not pure.

Or, it is said that it is called conventional because it is worldly knowledge that is attracted and produced by supramundane knowledge. Its substance is not knowledge, but it is called knowledge because knowledge is subordinate to it. This means that this name refers to impure knowledge.
Some say:
The various destinies are called conventional, and this knowledge is often the cause of going to the various destinies. It is named knowledge of the conventional from the point of view of the effect.
Some say:
This knowledge has been manifest and active in the body of beings since beginningless time, and for this reason it is called mundane knowledge.
Or, it is called mundane knowledge because it flows along with existence without interruption, because it is active in a series that accords with existence at all times.
Or, it is called mundane knowledge because it can illuminate all objects, because it alone is able to universally take all dharmas as objects.
The last pure knowledge is divided into two kinds, because it is called knowledge of dharmas and inferential knowledge.
The meanings of these two names have already been explained above.
However, there is an interpretation by a certain master that
inferential knowledge is called inferential because it infers from the presently seen event to the presently unseen object, and it is categorized as inference.
This interpretation is incorrect, because it is said to be true insight.

That is, a knowledge that is not a direct perception cannot be called true seeing. The scriptures in general say that the truths are seen in two ways, as real nature and as species. If one sees suffering as it really is, one definitely sees that it has no self. Because one sees the four noble truths as they really are, one is able to see the four noble truths as they really are.
There are innumerable scriptures such as this.

Also, there is equal and certain knowledge in the holy paths. That is, one who has seen the traces of the path definitely and certainly knows that all created dharmas are impermanent, that all dharmas are without self, and that nirvÄá¹‡a is quiescent. It is not true that one directly sees and knows that these are certain.
That is, one infers that they are of this class and that they are called certain knowledge, but they are not really certain, because there are differences.
Consequently, true seeing and inferential knowledge are not the same, and it is not correct to say that they are equal and certain. There is no principle of inferential knowledge in the holy wisdoms.
Therefore, a wise person would not say that there is an object of the holy truths that is realized by inferential knowledge.

Also, the holy path would not have knowledge of cessation as an object, because if knowledge of species is inferential knowledge, then knowledge of the law of cessation would not exist, because cessation in general is not a present, seen event.
However, there are three kinds of direct awareness: that which is based on the organs, that which is sensation, and that which is discernment.
Direct awareness based on the organs is the direct apprehension of the five external sense objects, form, etc., by means of the five organs.
Direct awareness as sensation is the present state of the mental activities of feeling, conceptualization, etc.
Direct awareness as discernment is the realization of the specific and common characteristics of all dharmas as they are.

If we say that the object of knowledge of species is not a present, seen event because it is based on the organs and is sensation, then knowledge of the law of cessation would not exist, because cessation is neither based on the organs nor a sensation.
If we say that the object of knowledge of species is the object of inferential knowledge, then we should not say that the object of knowledge of species is not a present, seen event.
Therefore all knowledge that is attracted by correct principle and that discerns the true meaning is direct awareness.

Since the same is true of the knowledge of the class of the path, it is also categorized as direct knowledge. These are the differences in characteristics of the two knowledges that result in three knowledges.

Holy knowledge associated with the mind in samÄdhi and that which occurs in post-samÄdhi both have as their mode of activity the contemplation of the characteristics of the four noble truths. How do we distinguish between the two knowledges, impure and pure?
Pure knowledge is clear and sharp in its mode of activity with regard to its object, while impure knowledge is the opposite of this.

It is like the difference between the burning power of charcoal made from khadira wood and that of charcoal made from other wood, and the difference in the power of the two kinds of charcoal to perfume.
The difference between the two knowledges is also like the difference in the heat of a fire that burns iron grass and an ordinary fire.
Or else, impure knowledge is followed by the conceit of superiority, but this is not so of pure knowledge, and this is the difference between the two.
Also, there is a difference between impure and pure knowledge in the breadth of their objects,

because impure knowledge takes as its object all conditioned and unconditioned dharmas, because a scripture says that impure knowledge is able to know completely the truth of suffering, and so on, up to the knowledge of space and non-analytical cessation.

There is also a view that the aspect of nonself takes as its object all dharmas in general, because a scripture says, The various formations are impermanent, all dharmas are without self, and nirvÄá¹‡a is quiescent.
However, there is a scripture that says,

Those who, with correct wisdom, contemplate all dharmas as without self, although all dharmas are in reality without self, the word all does not refer to all dharmas, but only to the suffering of the truth of suffering that is included in the aggregates. Therefore the scripture continues and says that one can then become disgusted with suffering.
Other sources interpret this passage as follows:

This wisdom is really able to take all dharmas as objects, but since the aspect of nonself is originally a means to become disgusted with suffering, the scripture only says that one becomes disgusted with suffering. It is like the case where one sets fire to a house and the fire spreads to other places.
This interpretation is not reasonable, because the scripture continues and says,
This path is powerful and can bring about purity.
If the wisdoms of listening and reflecting can universally take all dharmas as objects and contemplate them as without self, how can this path bring about a pure result?
If you say that this is said to be able to attain purity, and it is not said that this is the means of purification, then there is no error.
This is also unreasonable, because it is said in order to block other paths, as a scripture says:
Only this path can attain purity, there is no other path.
How can it be said there:

That which can attain purity is not the means of purification?ğŸ”½Therefore we know that this scripture says that the contemplation of all dharmas as non-self by means of right wisdom refers only to dharmas included in the truth of suffering, and does not include other dharmas. The word all is like saying that all conditioned dharmas are impermanent and suffering, but the noble path is not suffering or impermanent. Therefore the word all only applies to the truth of suffering.

This should also be so. Only the realm of suffering is contemplated as non-self, not other truths. Apart from this, there must definitely be a general contemplation of all dharmas as non-self, because it is known by contemplators.

That is, the contemplator must first cultivate the aspect of contemplating that all dharmas are non-self, purifying and conditioning the body so as to make it capable, and based on that, enter into the contemplation of the three meanings.

If it were not so, because it would be disturbed by the aspect of a unitary combined self, one would be unable to cultivate the contemplation of the non-confusion of establishing all dharmas without characteristics.
Dharma cognition only takes the four truths of the desire realm as its object, because the Abhidharma-Å›Ästra says:
What is dharma cognition?

It is undefiled cognition taking as its object the conditioned dharmas of the desire realm, undefiled cognition taking as its object the causes of the conditioned dharmas of the desire realm, undefiled cognition taking as its object the cessation of the conditioned dharmas of the desire realm, undefiled cognition taking as its object the path that can eliminate the conditioned dharmas of the desire realm, and undefiled cognition taking as its object dharma cognition and the stage of dharma cognition. This is called dharma cognition.
Isn't it that dharma cognition takes the four truths as its object? Why does it also say and undefiled cognition taking as its object dharma cognition and the stage of dharma cognition?

These two also have the truth of the path as their object, because the previous statement that pure knowledge that has as its object the practices of the realm of desire that can eliminate them cannot refer to all knowledge of the truth of the path, but only to that which can have as its object the path that can eliminate them.

In order to include that which has as its object the path of added effort, the path of liberation, and the path of distinction, and in order to include knowledge of the truth that has as its object the knowledge of the truth, and in order to include knowledge of the truth that arises in the body of one who has already eliminated desire and has as its object knowledge of the truth and the perseverance for knowledge of the truth, it again says that it has as its object knowledge of the truth and the stage of knowledge of the truth.

Or, the previous statement that knowledge that has as its object the path of elimination only refers to knowledge of the truth that has as its object the path of added effort of the stage of pre-trance that can oppose the elimination of that which is eliminated by insight and by cultivation in the realm of desire. In order to include knowledge of the truth that has as its object the class of knowledge of the truth of the five stages, it again speaks of the latter two.
In that case, that passage should be formulated as follows:
Pure knowledge that has as its object the antidote to the practices of the realm of desire.
If this is said, it includes all knowledge of the truth that has as its object the class of knowledge of the truth, because the word antidote has many meanings.
If it were so, then there would be the fault of non-love.

That is to say, the pure cognition taking the realm of form as its object would also be called cognition of the dharma realm, because the activities of the realm of form are included in the antidote to the activities of the realm of desire.
Isnâ€™t there also this fault in the statement that the cognition of the path of elimination taking the activities of the realm of desire as its object?
There is no such fault, because the words of the antidote have already excluded the antidote to the desire of the realm of form.

That is, this is based on the truth to distinguish the object of cognition of the dharma realm. The words of the path indicate that it is included in the truth of the path. The statement you make does not also have the words of the path, so this fault is yours, not mine.

Moreover, even if you allow that it has the words of the path, it still cannot include all the cognition of the dharma realm, because the cognition of the dharma realm is able to universally eliminate the three realms.

Moreover, you must also allow that all the pure cognitions of the class of cognition of the subsequent stage are included in the cognition of the dharma realm, because the class of cognition of the subsequent stage is also the antidote to the distant elimination of the realm of desire. This is because the words of the antidote are allowed to refer to many meanings.
For this reason, there is no fault in the explanation of the root text.
The class of knowledge is able to universally take as its object the four truths of the upper two realms. Because the objects of these three knowledges are different.
Within these three kinds of knowledge, the verse says:
The four knowledges of suffering, etc. are established based on the distinction of dharma and inferential knowledge by their objects.
They all pervade the knowledge of elimination and non-arising, but the first only has the class of suffering and accumulation.
The treatise says:
Dharma knowledge and inferential knowledge, based on the distinction of their objects, are divided into the four knowledges of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and path.
Why is it that conventional knowledge, although also taking suffering, etc. as its object and making suffering, etc. its aspects, is not the knowledge of suffering, etc.?
Because after previously contemplating suffering, etc. with the aspects of suffering, etc., one may later still contemplate the objects of suffering, etc. as bliss, etc.
Moreover, after attaining such conventional knowledge, it is possible for doubt regarding the truths to manifest again.
If these six knowledges are included in the category of post-learner, and are not of the nature of seeing, they are called the knowledge of elimination and non-arising.

These two first produced are only the species of the truths of suffering and of the cause of suffering, because they have as their objects the six aspects of the truths of suffering and of the cause of suffering and the aggregates of the peak of existence.
If the diamond-like samÄdhi has suffering and cause as objects, its objects are the same as these two, but it is different from the paths of cessation and the path.
If this is so, is there not a contradiction with the teachings?
As it is said:
When the first knowledge of the end of suffering is produced, one is able to understand it by oneself immediately after this.
There is no fault of contradicting the teachings, because the word end in the above passage is the seventh case, not the seventh case as an object.
That is, because the afflictions are completely ended without remainder, the first knowledge is produced. This knowledge produced does not have the end as an object. What is contradicted?
The meaning expressed by the above passage is that in a body with afflictions, this knowledge is not produced. Only when the afflictions are completely ended
Among the nine kinds of knowledge explained above, a verse says:
The knowledge of dharmas, inferential, path, conventional, and knowledge of others' minds may be accomplished.
One does not know superior stages, faculties, states, the past and future.
Dharma, inferential, and conventional knowledges do not know each other. ÅšrÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and buddhas,
Know the path of seeing in two, three, and all moments respectively.
The treatise says:
There are four knowledges - dharma, inferential, path, and conventional - that constitute the knowledge of others' minds. The others are not so.
Isn't it that the knowledge of the path is not apart from dharma and inferential? It should only be said that three constitute the knowledge of others' minds?
This is indeed the principle. In order to show that the knowledge of others' minds only knows the same kind of object, it is said like this.

That is to say, in order to show that this dharma and inferential knowledge knowing the uncontaminated mind and mental factors of others is included in the knowledge of the path, not in the knowledge of suffering and accumulation. Because uncontaminated knowledge definitely cannot know the contaminated mind and mental factors of others.
The uncontaminated mind and mental factors of another's body are subtle and superior, and are not the object of one's own contaminated knowledge of others' minds. The principle is reasonable.
For what reason can one's own uncontaminated knowledge of others' minds not know the contaminated mind and mental factors of others?
When pure knowledge arises with regard to contaminated objects, its mode of activity and objects are different from this knowledge.

That is, when pure knowledge takes contaminated objects, it must be a general mode of activity that is disgusted with the object. Therefore it definitely cannot take the mind and mental activities of another as objects and form knowledge of anotherâ€™s mind.
This is because when holy knowledge takes contaminated objects, it must be deeply disgusted with the object and is happy to abandon it generally and is not happy to contemplate it separately.
When it takes pure objects, it arises as a happy and joyful mode of activity. Having contemplated generally, it is also happy to contemplate separately.
When one sees or hears something that is not loved, one abandons it generally and is not happy to contemplate it separately.
When it is something loved, it is not like this. Having seen or heard it generally, one is also happy to contemplate it separately.

Therefore there is definitely no holy knowledge that contemplates the mind and mental activities of another separately, one by one, and forms knowledge of anotherâ€™s mind with regard to contaminated objects. This is because knowledge of anotherâ€™s mind definitely knows the mind and mental activities of another separately.
Arenâ€™t there also three moments of patience and knowledge of suffering and accumulation that are included in the three moments of mindfulness?
Although there are, they are not only based on one dharma, because they are based on many substances.

Moreover, knowledge of othersâ€™ minds has a definite characteristic, namely, it does not know superior minds of the two time periods of the past and future, nor do the classes of patience and knowledge of suffering and origin mutually know each other.
Superior has three kinds, namely, stage, faculty, and state.
Stage means that knowledge of a lower stage does not know the mind of a higher stage. The meaning is that it can only know its own stage and lower stages.
Faculty means that knowledge of the faculties of faith-and-understanding and time-liberation does not know the minds of the faculties of seeing-and-conquering and non-time-liberation.

State means that the knowledge of the states of non-returners, Å›rÄvaka arhats, pratyekabuddhas, and great buddhas does not know the minds of the superior states of later ones. The meaning is that it can only know its own stage and lower faculties.

However, the knowledge of othersâ€™ minds and the objects of knowledge, the faculties and stages being different, the knowledge is also different. The contaminated minds and mental factors that are known have each had fifteen that have not yet been obtained.
That is, the four meditations of the desire realm can be known by those of lower, middle, and upper faculties.
But excluding the three grades of the desire realm, which have never been attained, each has twelve.
The known pure and the knowing are all excluded from the three of desire, each having twelve.

Moreover, the impure, which have never been attained, are included in the lower faculties. The knowledge of others that arises can know the three grades of mind of the lower stages as appropriate. The lower middle grade also knows the middle grade of its own stage, and the upper grade comprehensively understands the three of its own lower stages.
When the pure knowledge of others arises, it only knows the lower faculties of its own lower stage, the middle also knows the middle, and the upper also knows the upper.
Why is there a difference in the amount of lower stage minds known when impure and pure knowledge arises?

The three grades of the impure can be accomplished in one lifetime, but the pure are established according to the faculties of the noble ones. There is not even one who accomplishes two grades of faculties, let alone three.
Therefore there is a difference.
How can it be said that one person creates nine classes of paths to eliminate nine classes of passions?

The differences in these paths are not due to differences in faculties, but because the cause gradually increases and the subsequent path increases and can cause the elimination of many classes of passions.
Or, the various natures each have nine classes. If one creates nine classes, one necessarily does not create the others. Therefore there is no error in the above and later statements.

Therefore, when one creates a mind of a lower faculty in dependence on a higher stage, there is a mind of a higher faculty in dependence on a lower stage. The higher and lower stages and faculties are mutually exclusive and do not know each other. The same is true of the relationship between the various stages and faculties.
This knowledge of others minds does not know the past and future, because it originally knows dharmas such as mind and mental activities that can be objects of the mind.

The two classes of knowledge of dharmas and knowledge of the four truths do not mutually know each other, because these two, respectively, take as their objects all the antidote of the realm of desire and the realm of form.

This knowledge of others minds does not exist in the path of insight, because it is a rapid and general observation of the truth. However, it is possible for it to be the object of the knowledge of others minds.

translated: When the holy ones of the three vehicles generate this knowledge, those of the two lower vehicles must add effort. The added effort of the Å›rÄvaka is either superior or middling, and the pratyekabuddha only needs inferior added effort. The Buddha has no added effort and manifests it at will.

If sentient beings are about to enter the path of insight, the Å›rÄvaka and pratyekabuddha cultivate added effort in advance in order to know the mind in the state of the path of insight of those sentient beings.

When those sentient beings enter the path of insight, if the added effort of the Å›rÄvaka is complete with regard to the class of dharmas, he knows the mind of the first two moments of the path of insight of those sentient beings.

If it is in order to know the mind of the class of species again, he cultivates added effort separately until the added effort is complete. Those sentient beings have already passed to the sixteenth moment. Although he knows this mind, he does not know the path of insight. Therefore it is said that he only knows two moments.
If the added effort of the pratyekabuddha with regard to the class of dharmas is complete, he knows the mind of the first two moments of the path of insight of those sentient beings.

If it is in order to know the mind of the class of species again, he cultivates added effort separately until the added effort is complete. He knows the eighth moment of the mind of the path of insight of those sentient beings, which is the knowledge of the class of species that is the result of the knowledge of the law in the path of insight.
Other masters say that it knows the fifteenth moment, and still others say that the rhinoceros knows four moments.
That is, the first two moments and the eighth and fourteenth moments.
This explanation is reasonable.
Why is this?
It is admitted that after knowing the first two moments of thought, it knows the eighth moment after only five moments.
If it cultivates the added efforts of the dharma of discernment, then in five moments the added efforts should be completed. Why not admit that it knows the fourteenth moment?
Other masters say that it knows four moments, that is, the first two moments and the eleventh and twelfth moments.

Because the Buddha freely controls his mind and can manifest any superior quality he wishes, he can know in fifteen moments in succession, because the World Honored One, through the cultivation of immeasurable requisites for conversion over three incalculable eons, has acquired inconceivable, superior, marvelous knowledge endowed with great power and can know as he wishes.

Even though this knowledge arises and also knows mental activities, the fundamental added effort is for the sake of knowing mind, just as the knowledge of others is called knowledge of the base of infinite space, etc.
The Venerable PÄrÅ›va says:
In order to induce the arising of this knowledge, one must first know the mind and then know the object. From the beginning, it is only called knowledge of others' minds.
When inducing this knowledge, what preparatory practices are cultivated?
One should first observe the manifest form of the body, the pleasant speech, and the mental differences expressed.

That is to say, when the practitioner is first cultivating, in order to discern the differences in others' minds, they first carefully observe the differences in their own manifest form, pleasant speech, and causes, and thus know that the differences in manifest form, etc. are due to the mind.
Next, they carefully observe the manifest form, etc. of others, and also know that they arise with differences due to the differences in the mind.

Because of this, at a later time, the body and mind are subdued and purified, and the supreme concentration is induced. Relying on concentration, the powerful knowledge arises. This knowledge truly illuminates the minds of others, just as the various colors and differences in a bright pearl can be clearly seen. This is called the preparatory practice for cultivating the knowledge of others' minds in the conventional sense.

If one cultivates the uncontaminated knowledge of others' minds, using the knowledge of suffering that observes impermanence, etc., as the added effort, this added effort stage generally takes form and mind as objects. When it is perfected, it takes mind as its object, not form.
Moreover, in the added effort stage, it takes one's own and others' minds as objects. When it is perfected, it takes others' minds as objects, not one's own.
What are the two characteristics of the knowledge of elimination and the knowledge of non-arising?
The verse says:
The knowledge of the four noble truths, knowing I have already known and so forth,
I should not know again and so forth, are respectively the knowledge of elimination and non-arising.
The treatise says:
As the Abhidharma-Å›Ästra says, what is the knowledge of elimination?
It is said that in the state of no-more-learning, if one correctly knows for oneself:
I have already known suffering, I have already eliminated accumulation, I have already realized cessation, I have already cultivated the path.
The wisdom, vision, illumination, understanding, discernment, insight, and contemplation that arise from this are called the knowledge of elimination.
What is the knowledge of non-arising?
That is, one correctly knows, I have already known suffering and need not know it again, and so on, up to I have already cultivated the path and need not cultivate it again.
This is called the knowledge of nonarising.
When the two knowledges occur due to the original intention, they are able to induce this kind of understanding-knowledge.
When the two pure knowledges occur, one does not have this kind of understanding, because they are nondiscriminating.

That is, after the two knowledges have emerged, in the subsequently acquired knowledge one makes this kind of twofold discrimination. These two discriminations arise after the two knowledges, because they are induced by the power of the knowledge of elimination and nonarising.
These two conventional knowledges are the effect of the dominant power of those two knowledges. Therefore, the two fruits are mentioned to indicate the difference between the two knowledges.
This must necessarily be so, because it is said that it is on account of this.
The meaning of this is that the sound on account of this is the same as the meaning of the knowledge that exists on account of this.
Otherwise, one would have to say that all contemplatives and practitioners, when they originally cultivate the path, must generate this kind of intention and resolve.
That is, when I realize arhatship, I must arouse this knowledge that examines myself. Therefore, when I emerge from contemplation, this knowledge must be born.
